ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An introduction to deaf culture, vocabulary regarding introductions, family, relationships, activities, foods, likes and dislikes.
ability to have basic conversations in asl, knowledge about deaf culture and current deaf issues, understanding of the general structure of asl and differences from spoken English

Coming to this class with little to no knowledge of Deaf culture, the Deaf community, or sign language; I have learned so much ASL vocabulary, aspects of Deaf culture and a Deaf identity. I am able to craft sentences and create stories and poems, as well as communicate to members of the Deaf community through outreach events. I now have a better understanding of Deaf culture and the forms of stigma that the hearing community perpetuates.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Clearer expectations for out-of-class community hours from the beginning of the course.

Few improvements. I only think the parameters/expectations for the service hours could be made clearer. I feel like they changed quite a few times through out the course of the semester (in terms of how many hours we would need in total/breakdown of each component).

Really kind instructors who are willing to help outside of class. I like that they center engaging with deaf culture through the community service hours.

A lot of class time was used to practice having conversations, which was really helpful in becoming more comfortable using the language. I would have liked to have some sort of "vocab list" (maybe a video going through all the new signs in a unit and their translations) for more vocab-heavy units, as this would have been helpful to refer to when studying.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, ASL is a great language to learn and will open your eyes to deaf culture, which was really interesting to learn about.

Yes! I have absolutely loved taking ASL; it's a great tool for communication, pushes you to think about how to express ideas in a unique way, and teaches you a lot about deaf culture. This course gave me a great foundation in the language and has made me really excited to continue taking ASL at Yale. Yale's ASL community is also really great in helping you learn the language, from official ASL events to just practicing with peers.

I would strongly recommend this course if a person wants to explore the beauty and creativity that comes with ASL and the Deaf community as a whole. This is a great introductory course to the language and to Deaf culture as a whole.
